title: How your muscular system works - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the muscular system?

options.label: B
options.text: To facilitate movement and maintain posture

options.label: C
options.text: To produce energy for the body

options.label: D
options.text: To filter waste from the blood

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following muscle types is responsible for the heart's dependable thump?
A sprinter's legs contain more of which type of muscle fiber to quickly pick up the pace?
What is the primary function of the autonomic nervous system in relation to the muscular system?

options.label: D
options.text: To filter waste from the blood

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following muscle types is responsible for maintaining posture?
What is the primary function of the stapedius muscle?
A person's heart thumps roughly 3 billion times over the course of their life, which supplies the body with what?
What is the primary function of the buccinator muscle?

options.label: D
options.text: To attach the cheek to the teeth

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the slow-twitch muscle fibers?

options.label: C
options.text: To generate most of the body's motion

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the body's warmth is provided by muscle?

title: The strange case of the cyclops sheep - Tien Nguyen

multiple-choice.question: What was the unusual deformity found in the lambs born to sheep in Idaho in the 1950s?
What was the name of the molecule responsible for causing the deformity in the lambs?
What was the name of the gene that, when mutated, produced pointy spikes like a hedgehog in fruit flies?
What was the outcome when Professor Philip Beachy and his colleagues turned off the hedgehog gene in mice?

options.label: C
options.text: The mice developed severe defects in brain, organ, and eye development

multiple-choice.question: What was the role of the hedgehog protein in normal healthy development?

options.label: B
options.text: It allowed the smoothened protein to freely signal the cells

options.label: C
options.text: It bound onto the smoothened protein

options.label: D
options.text: It was responsible for causing the cyclops deformity

multiple-choice.question: What was the effect of cyclopamine on the smoothened protein?

options.label: A
options.text: It allowed the smoothened protein to freely signal the cells

options.label: C
options.text: It locked the smoothened protein up so that it was unable to send the signals needed to mold the brain into two hemispheres

options.label: D
options.text: It had no effect on the smoothened protein

multiple-choice.question: What human syndrome is associated with uncontrolled activation of the smoothened protein?
What was the proposed use of cyclopamine's smoothened binding powers?

options.label: A
options.text: As a treatment for the cyclops deformity

options.label: B
options.text: As a treatment for Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome

options.label: C
options.text: As a treatment for skin cancer

options.label: D
options.text: As a treatment for fruit fly mutations

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the researchers' efforts to develop cyclopamine as a treatment for skin cancer?

options.label: A
options.text: It was approved as a treatment for skin cancer in 2012

options.label: B
options.text: It was approved as a treatment for skin cancer in 2015

options.label: C
options.text: It was found to be safe and effective, but its chemical properties made it difficult to work with, and closely related molecules were developed as safer alternatives

options.label: D
options.text: It was not effective in treating skin cancer

multiple-choice.question: What can be inferred about the decision of the farmers to investigate the cyclops sheep?

options.label: A
options.text: They were primarily motivated by financial gain

options.label: B
options.text: They were primarily motivated by curiosity

options.label: C
options.text: They were primarily motivated by a desire to understand the science behind the deformity

options.label: D
options.text: They were primarily motivated by a desire to exploit the situation for personal benefit

title: A brief history of banned numbers - Alessandra King

multiple-choice.question: Who discovered irrational numbers, which were perceived as a threat to the Pythagorean's notion of a perfect universe?
What was the main reason the Pythagorean school was challenged by the discovery of irrational numbers?

options.label: A
options.text: The numbers were too difficult to calculate.

options.label: B
options.text: The numbers were too easy to forge or alter.

options.label: C
options.text: The numbers were incompatible with the Pythagorean's notion of a perfect universe.

options.label: D
options.text: The numbers were not suitable for large transactions.

multiple-choice.question: What advantage did the Hindu-Arabic numeral system have over the Roman numeral system?

options.label: A
options.text: The Hindu-Arabic numeral system allowed for the representation of large numbers.

options.label: B
options.text: The Hindu-Arabic numeral system enabled the concept of negative numbers and zero.

options.label: C
options.text: The Hindu-Arabic numeral system facilitated the development of algebraic equations.

options.label: D
options.text: The Hindu-Arabic numeral system had no significant impact on the representation of numbers.

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of the discovery of irrational numbers on the Pythagorean school?

options.label: A
options.text: The Pythagorean school's notion of a perfect universe was challenged, leading to a re-evaluation of their mathematical principles.

options.label: B
options.text: The Hindu-Arabic numeral system was replaced by the Roman numeral system.

options.label: C
options.text: The discovery of irrational numbers led to the development of a new branch of mathematics that focused on the properties of numbers.

options.label: D
options.text: The Pythagorean school's discovery of irrational numbers had no significant impact on the Hindu-Arabic numeral system.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the idea that some numbers may be considered illegal?

options.label: A
options.text: It highlights the potential risks of using numbers to represent sensitive information, such as protected data or state secrets.

options.label: B
options.text: It emphasizes the importance of using numbers in a way that is transparent and open to interpretation.

options.label: C
options.text: It suggests that numbers are not as powerful as words in conveying meaning.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no significant impact on the relationship between numbers and words.

multiple-choice.question: Who was concerned about the ease of forgery or alteration of the Hindu-Arabic numeral system?
What is the potential consequence of using numbers to represent sensitive information?

options.label: A
options.text: The numbers will be more difficult to calculate.

options.label: B
options.text: The numbers will be more easily forged or altered.

options.label: C
options.text: Possessing or publishing these numbers may be treated as a criminal offense.

options.label: D
options.text: The numbers will lose their symbolic meaning.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the idea that numbers are a way of expressing concepts and information?

options.label: A
options.text: It highlights the potential risks of using numbers to represent sensitive information.

options.label: B
options.text: It emphasizes the importance of using numbers in a way that is transparent and open to interpretation.

options.label: C
options.text: It suggests that numbers are not as powerful as words in conveying meaning.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no significant impact on the relationship between numbers and words.

multiple-choice.question: In what century was Florence banned from using the Hindu-Arabic numeral system for record keeping?
Who was a prominent mathematician who avoided using zero in his calculations?

title: Are you a body with a mind or a mind with a body? - Maryam Alimardani

multiple-choice.question: What is the rubber hand illusion?

options.label: A
options.text: A technique used to measure the strength of a person's hand

options.label: B
options.text: An experiment where a dummy hand is placed in front of a person and their real hand is hidden behind a screen

options.label: C
options.text: A type of virtual reality experience

options.label: D
options.text: A way to increase a person's sense of self-awareness

multiple-choice.question: According to René Descartes, what is the ultimate proof of our existence?

options.label: A
options.text: Our ability to think and reason

options.label: C
options.text: Our mind and thoughts, even if all physical sensations are just a hallucinatory dream

options.label: D
options.text: Our ability to move our bodies

multiple-choice.question: If we accept that the mind is non-physical, how can it interact with the physical body?

options.label: A
options.text: The mind can move the body through a direct connection

options.label: B
options.text: The mind can move the body through a series of complex chemical reactions

options.label: C
options.text: The mind can move the body through the assistance of external forces, such as God

options.label: D
options.text: The mind cannot interact with the physical body

multiple-choice.question: According to neuroscience, what is the relationship between our bodies and brains?

options.label: A
options.text: Our bodies and brains are separate entities

options.label: B
options.text: Our bodies and brains are deeply integrated to form consciousness

options.label: C
options.text: Our brains control our bodies, but our bodies do not affect our brains

options.label: D
options.text: Our bodies affect our brains, but our brains do not affect our bodies

options.label: A
options.text: Our senses can easily mislead us in our judgment of self

options.label: B
options.text: Our bodies and external sensations are inseparable from our subjective consciousness

options.label: C
options.text: Our minds are separate from our bodies

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The transfer of a human consciousness into a new mind

options.label: A
options.text: Our bodies are separate from our consciousness

options.label: B
options.text: Our bodies are part of our consciousness

options.label: C
options.text: Our consciousness is separate from our bodies

options.label: A
options.text: To prove the existence of God

options.label: B
options.text: To prove the existence of the material world

options.label: C
options.text: To prove the existence of the mind and thoughts, even if all physical sensations are just a hallucinatory dream

options.label: D
options.text: To prove the existence of the body

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the relationship between our brains and bodies?

options.label: C
options.text: Our brains and bodies are separate entities

options.label: D
options.text: Our brains and bodies are deeply integrated to form consciousness

multiple-choice.question: What is the open question discussed in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: What is the nature of the material world?

options.label: B
options.text: What is the nature of the mind and body?

options.label: C
options.text: What is the nature of consciousness?

options.label: D
options.text: What is the nature of the self?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of virtual reality experience

options.label: B
options.text: A type of wearable device that can become extended parts of our bodies

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Our bodies are part of our consciousness

options.label: C

title: Should we get rid of standardized testing? - Arlo Kempf

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary use of standardized tests during the Han dynasty in China?

options.label: A
options.text: To evaluate aptitude for various government posts

multiple-choice.question: What does a percentile represent in the context of standardized tests?

options.label: A
options.text: The percentage of test takers who scored above a certain threshold

options.label: B
options.text: The percentage of test takers who scored below a certain threshold

options.label: C
options.text: The percentage of test takers who scored exactly the same as a certain threshold

options.label: D
options.text: The percentage of test takers who scored better than a certain threshold

multiple-choice.question: How can standardized tests be used to evaluate the performance of firefighters in France?

options.label: A
options.text: By comparing their stair climb times to those of other firefighters

multiple-choice.question: What are two critical ideas for understanding standardized tests?
What can happen if standardized tests are given the wrong job or are not designed properly?

options.label: A
options.text: They may measure the right things

options.label: B
options.text: They may measure the wrong things

multiple-choice.question: What are some potential limitations of standardized tests in measuring abstract characteristics or skills?

options.label: A
options.text: They may not be able to measure creativity, critical thinking, and collaboration

options.label: B
options.text: They may not be able to measure physical abilities

options.label: C
options.text: They may not be able to measure academic learning

options.label: D
options.text: They may not be able to measure language proficiency

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between an unreliable thermometer and a reliable but invalid thermometer?

options.label: A
options.text: An unreliable thermometer gives different readings each time, while a reliable but invalid thermometer gives consistently incorrect readings

options.label: B
options.text: An unreliable thermometer gives consistently incorrect readings, while a reliable but invalid thermometer gives different readings each time

options.label: C
options.text: An unreliable thermometer gives accurate readings, while a reliable but invalid thermometer gives inaccurate readings

options.label: D
options.text: An unreliable thermometer gives inaccurate readings, while a reliable but invalid thermometer gives accurate readings

multiple-choice.question: What can happen if people misinterpret the results of a standardized test?

options.label: A
options.text: The test may become more reliable

options.label: B
options.text: The test may become more valid

options.label: C
options.text: The test may become less reliable

multiple-choice.question: What is one potential consequence of relying too heavily on standardized test scores?

options.label: A
options.text: Test scores may become more accurate

options.label: B
options.text: Test scores may become more reliable

options.label: C
options.text: Test scores may lead to sweeping and often negative changes for test takers

options.label: D
options.text: Test scores may become less valid

multiple-choice.question: What is the responsibility of educators and policymakers when using standardized tests?

options.label: A
options.text: To design tests that measure the wrong things

options.label: C
options.text: To use the right tests for the right jobs and to interpret results appropriately

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore the results of standardized tests

title: How do executive orders work? - Christina Greer

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary effect of Abraham Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation?

options.label: A
options.text: It abolished slavery in the entire United States.

options.label: B
options.text: It changed the status of over 3 million enslaved blacks from slave to free.

options.label: C
options.text: It established the Works Progress Administration.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between a law and an executive order?

options.label: A
options.text: A law is created by the president, while an executive order is created by Congress.

options.label: B
options.text: A law is created by Congress, while an executive order is created by the president without consultation or permission from Congress.

options.label: C
options.text: A law is enforced by the president, while an executive order is enforced by Congress.

options.label: D
options.text: A law is created without consultation or permission from Congress, while an executive order is created with consultation and permission from Congress.

multiple-choice.question: How can a president use an executive order to exert power without working with Congress?

options.label: A
options.text: By responding to emergencies and making quick decisions.

options.label: B
options.text: By using an executive order to expand or contract the power of agencies in the federal government.

multiple-choice.question: What are some examples of how executive orders have changed the course of American history?

options.label: A
options.text: FDR's Works Progress Administration and Harry Truman's desegregation of the armed forces.

options.label: B
options.text: FDR's 1942 executive order and Lyndon Johnson's establishment of requirements for nondiscriminatory practices in hiring and employment.

options.label: C
options.text: William Henry Harrison's lack of executive orders and the U.S. Constitution's ambiguity on the extent of the president's power.

options.label: D
options.text: FDR's Works Progress Administration, Harry Truman's desegregation of the armed forces, FDR's 1942 executive order, and Lyndon Johnson's establishment of requirements for nondiscriminatory practices in hiring and employment.

multiple-choice.question: What are some of the limitations of executive orders?

options.label: A
options.text: They can only be created by the president, and they can only be enforced by Congress.

options.label: B
options.text: They can be created by the president, but they can be halted by Congress or judges if deemed unconstitutional.

options.label: C
options.text: They can only be used in times of crisis or emergency.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not subject to judicial review.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a negative use of an executive order?

options.label: B
options.text: Harry Truman's desegregation of the armed forces.

options.label: D
options.text: Lyndon Johnson's establishment of requirements for nondiscriminatory practices in hiring and employment.

multiple-choice.question: How has the number of executive orders issued by presidents changed over time?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of executive orders has decreased over time.

options.label: B
options.text: The number of executive orders has remained relatively constant over time.

options.label: C
options.text: The number of executive orders has increased over time, with FDR issuing over 3,500 and each subsequent president issuing roughly 300.

options.label: D
options.text: The number of executive orders has decreased significantly since the early 1960s.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the U.S. Constitution's ambiguity on the extent of the president's power?

options.label: A
options.text: It has resulted in a decrease in the number of executive orders issued.

options.label: B
options.text: It has resulted in an increase in the number of executive orders issued, as presidents have begun to assert their power.

options.label: C
options.text: It has resulted in a lack of clarity on the role of the executive branch.

options.label: D
options.text: It has resulted in a decrease in the effectiveness of executive orders.

multiple-choice.question: How can Congress and judges use checks and balances to limit the power of executive orders?

options.label: A
options.text: By passing laws to counteract executive orders and by halting them if deemed unconstitutional.

options.label: B
options.text: By ignoring the Constitution and allowing executive orders to go unchecked.

options.label: C
options.text: By responding to emergencies and making quick decisions.

options.label: D
options.text: By creating new executive orders to counteract existing ones.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential impact of executive orders on the course of history?

options.label: A
options.text: They can only have a positive impact.

options.label: B
options.text: They can only have a negative impact.

options.label: C
options.text: They can have both positive and negative impacts, depending on how they are used.

options.label: D
options.text: They are irrelevant to the course of history.

title: Where do new words come from? - Marcel Danesi

multiple-choice.question: Approximately how many new words are added to the Oxford English Dictionary each year?
What is one way English words have been formed from other languages?

options.label: A
options.text: By creating new words from scratch

options.label: B
options.text: By combining existing words to create new meanings

options.label: C
options.text: By borrowing words directly from other languages

options.label: D
options.text: By changing the meaning of existing words without influence from other languages

options.label: B
options.text: By borrowing words from other languages

options.label: C
options.text: By using classical languages or combining existing words

options.label: D
options.text: By using words from other fields of study

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the process of words gaining new meanings over time?
What is a key factor in determining whether a new word becomes part of our everyday language?

options.label: B
options.text: Scientists and companies giving them official names

options.label: C
options.text: Ordinary people spreading words that hit the right combination of useful and catchy

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a word that was derived from an Ancient Greek word for a concept related to science?
According to the transcript, what is the term for words that describe themselves?
What is the phenomenon described by Richard Dawkins, where ideas and symbols propagate through a culture like genes through a population?
According to the transcript, how do ideas and symbols become popularized?

options.label: D
options.text: Through the process of imitation, as described by Richard Dawkins

multiple-choice.question: What can be learned about our world and how we communicate within it by studying the way words are created and become part of our language?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: That we communicate in a complex and multifaceted way

options.label: C

options.label: D

Where does the average t-shirt begin its life?

options.text: On a farm in America, China, or India

What is a significant environmental impact of cotton production?

options.label: A
options.text: Cotton requires a lot of water, but not pesticides.

options.label: B

title: The left brain vs. right brain myth - Elizabeth Waters

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea presented in the transcript about the left and right sides of the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: The left side of the brain controls logic and the right side controls creativity.

options.label: B
options.text: It allows for the brain to process information more efficiently.

options.label: C
options.text: It is not known why we have a crossing over of visual fields.

options.label: D
options.text: It allows for faster movement and quicker reflexes.

options.text: That the left side of the brain controls logic and the right side controls creativity.

options.text: To provide a reliable and sustainable source of energy

title: Why are sloths so slow? - Kenny Coogan

multiple-choice.question: What did Thomas Jefferson receive in 1796 that he couldn't identify?

options.label: B
options.text: A box of bones from a lion

options.label: D
options.text: A box of bones from a giant sloth

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary food source of the giant sloths that contributed to the spread of avocado trees?

options.label: C
options.text: Grasses and seeds and other plants

multiple-choice.question: What were some of the possible factors that contributed to the extinction of the giant sloths around 10,000 years ago?

options.label: B
options.text: Climate change due to an oncoming ice age

options.label: C
options.text: Competition with other species, including humans

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the physical adaptations that sloths have developed to cope with their restricted diet?

options.label: A
options.text: A multi-chambered stomach that takes up a third of their body

options.label: B
options.text: A slow metabolism that allows them to conserve energy

options.label: C
options.text: A long, sharp claw that helps them climb trees

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why sloths have a slow metabolism?

options.label: B
options.text: Because they have a large body size

options.label: C
options.text: Because they have a restricted diet that is low in energy

multiple-choice.question: How do sloths use their slow metabolism to their advantage in their treetop habitat?

options.label: A
options.text: They use it to conserve energy and stay warm

options.label: B
options.text: They use it to move quickly and catch prey

options.label: C
options.text: They use it to climb trees and escape predators

options.label: D
options.text: They don't use it to their advantage

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the benefits of the algae that grows on sloths?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides extra camouflage for the sloths

options.label: B
options.text: It provides a source of food for the sloths

options.label: C
options.text: It helps to regulate the sloths' body temperature

options.label: D
options.text: It has no benefits for the sloths

multiple-choice.question: Why do sloths spend most of their time eating, resting, or sleeping?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are trying to conserve energy due to their slow metabolism

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are trying to escape predators

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are trying to adapt to their environment

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the reasons why sloths have a multi-chambered stomach that takes up to 30% of their body?

options.label: A
options.text: To extract as much energy as possible from their food

options.label: B
options.text: To store food for later use

options.label: C
options.text: To help them digest their food quickly

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following sloths has the slowest metabolism?
How often do sloths descend from the canopy to the ground?
How long does it take a sloth to cross an average neighborhood street?
